div.head: Section 10
div.p: The fifth consideration: Our kings of the Spains are bound by necessity of precept and therefore by necessity of salvation both as to their first entry or that of their messengers into those Indian parts and world, and as to all other things which would have to be done by them concerning the aforesaid peoples, to order, moderate, and dispose them in such a way that they may conduce or be suitable to the aforesaid end which God and his vicar intend, namely the preaching of the gospel and the expansion of the faith and the planting of divine worship and the conversion and salvation of souls.

And consequently they are obligated by natural and divine law to avoid and guard against all those things which could totally impede the prenoted end or in any way retard it, or make its attainment difficult.

¶ The first part is proven thus: Whoever necessarily has the duty to perfect something which is ordered to another as a means to an end, is bound first to attend to this, that his work, that is the means, be congruous to the end, just as the smith makes a sword so that it may be suitable for fighting, and the builder so arranges a house that it may be apt for dwelling. But the advent, application, and entry
into those parts of our kings or their messengers, and also the regime or government which they are about to establish, and the total office or jurisdiction or power newly conferred on them, are assumed as means conducing and helping toward the attainment of the aforesaid end, as can be gathered from what has been said. Therefore they must be congruous or suitable and patronize the aforesaid end, and thus conduce and help so that the end may be obtained. The consequence is clear, because according to the Philosopher in Physics 2, of all things to be ordered to the end, the reasons and rules of government and of the order of law must necessarily be taken from the end, just as the reason for the disposition of a saw is taken from the cutting which is its end. And in human laws it is held that an act ordered and determined to some end ought to attain that end, ff. simul herciscus l. si filia § Item scribit C. ad sclli l. penultima in fine. Concerning this Baldus, By which causes a feud is lost c. 1. nu. 5.

¶ For then any thing is best disposed when it is suitably ordered and led to its end. Hence everything which is for the sake of an end must be proportioned to the end, so that it may help toward the attainment of the end.

Thus therefore our kings of the Spains will then well and suitably dispose their advent, application, or entry, or that of their messengers, into and to those parts of the Western and Southern Indies, and also their regime or government, jurisdiction, and the whole royal office, when in exercising all these things they will inviolably preserve to the letter the order of natural law. For order, which anyone is bound to preserve, is the mode of doing any thing, or according to Baldus in the proem of the Digests at the beginning:
It is joining principles to means and means to their ends, which being omitted, nothing is done rightly
ff. de regulis iuris l. sicut nulla and C. de sententiis et interlocutionibus l. probatam and de rescriptis c. cum dilecta and de restitutione spoliatorum c. pisanis.

¶ But there is a twofold order: one induced by civil or positive law, and its defect does not vitiate the act or process before a prince, because he is not bound by laws since he is above the law,
l. digna vox C. de legibus
and l. princeps ff. eo c. proposuit de concessione prebende.

¶ But there is another order founded upon natural law, such as that sentence be delivered with the party summoned, and if that order is omitted, the sentence is not valid, as in the Clementine pastoralis
de re iudicata, concerning which see Panormitanus in c. in causis de re iudicata and Angelus in d. l. princeps and all in d. clemen. pastoralis.

¶ When that order is omitted, the faculty of defending himself is given by law to anyone, even against the treasury and the messengers of the prince, without first making faith through letters by which the justice may be made known to all whose interest it is. To those wishing to seize the goods of others, even those which are borne to the treasury, anyone whose interest it is can resist in fact, and as punishment for not observing the order of law, the loss of the cause is even inflicted on the treasury itself, as in
l. prohibitum
and
l. iustas
and
l. defensionis facultas C. de iure fisci lib. 10 . And this deservedly, because nothing inordinate pleases the law, as Baldus notes in c. dilecti El. 3. de appel. and the thing is assumed by others in c. Romana eo titulo lib. 6. And for this it is further said that a commission made by the pope against the order of law, among non-subjects or among laymen, or perhaps against laymen in patrimonial matters, is not valid. John of Imola notes this in d. cap. clementina pastoralis. Nor can he remove the judicial order as regards the forum of laymen, the gloss notes in clementina dispendiosam de iudiciis. And an excellent argument that he who enters by a bad order, having omitted something which he ought to have done— for instance, if a consul enters the consulship having omitted the oath, concerning which in
c. consules de pace constantie in libro feudarum
—he is to be removed from there and also punished, as in l. 1 § necessario ff. si mulier ventris nomine and in
libro feudarum de milite vasalla qui contumax est c. 1 § si vero , where it is said that
what is done by bad order ought to be reformed , etc.
¶ But there is an order founded in natural and divine law which must necessarily be observed in this business, so that our first entry may be pacific and the progress just, as will be clear below.

¶ Therefore, our kings observing the aforesaid order founded upon natural law, to the observance of which they are obligated by precept of divine and natural law, it will necessarily follow that they will be understood to have applied congruous, proportioned, and due means to such an end, and consequently the peoples and nations inhabiting that world will be efficaciously provoked to hear the promulgation of the gospel and to receive the faith and to imitate Christian and religious morals, and thus deservedly they will then be said to be suitably led to their end.

¶ The second part of this fifth consideration, which is a consequence of the first, namely that our kings are bound by natural and divine law to avoid all things which can in any way retard or make difficult the attainment of the aforesaid end,
is proven.

First, because all that which renders an action inconvenient to the end which God or nature intends from some work is said to be against natural or divine law. But if in the advent and application or in the first entry of our kings or their messengers into those Indian regions and world, or in the progress, that is, in the regime or government, or in any other of those things which necessarily must be done by our illustrious kings concerning those Indian nations, there should happen to be some disorder, injustice, scandal, or some other undue work and not according to reason, or done against the order of law, which is of itself apt to generate in such infidels a sinister or perverse opinion concerning the faith or Christian religion, and to be a cause that they may be reasonably moved with capital hatred against the Christian people professing the name of Christ, they would render the actions of our kings, and those things which necessarily must be done by them concerning those peoples, inconvenient to and disproportioned to the end which God intends and also natural reason dictates, namely the preaching of the gospel and the conversion of those peoples themselves, and also temporal peace and quiet and complete utility, indeed their salvation.

Therefore our kings are bound by natural and divine law to avoid and guard against all injustice, scandal, disorder, burdens, and all other things which will be of themselves apt to disturb those peoples and to generate scandal among them, and moreover to think badly concerning faith and Christian religion or also Christian morals, all of which will yield to the offense of the gospel and will without doubt redound to the ignominy of the name of Christ, and consequently, who, I pray, will ever doubt that it will not only retard or make difficult the attainment of the aforesaid end, but totally impede it?

The minor is clear of itself. ¶ But the major is from
Saint Thomas in 4 Sentences distinction 33 question 1 article 1 in the body and article 3 in the body , where he says that
that action is said to be against the law of nature which is not suitable to the due end ,
whether because it is of itself disproportioned to that end, or because it altogether impedes the end or makes difficult or less decent
the arrival at the end.
And if the action is inconvenient to the end as entirely prohibiting the principal end, it is directly prohibited by the law of nature by the first precepts of the law of nature, which are in operables as common conceptions are in speculative matters. But if making difficult or less congruous the arrival at the end itself, it is prohibited by the second precepts of the law of nature, which are derived from the first, just as conclusions in speculative matters have faith from self-evident principles. And thus the said action is said to be against the law of nature . These things Saint Thomas.

¶ The consequence is proven because our kings are bound to observe the first and second, especially negative, precepts of the law of nature and divine law; otherwise they would sin mortally. For they are prohibited by negative precepts (as has been proven) from directly impeding the end or rendering difficult the attainment of the end which God or nature intends to elicit from the work of our kings, namely the preaching of the faith in the manner according to which it ought to be done according to the form established by Christ, the conversion of those living in those lands and seas, and their complete utility, not only spiritual but temporal, since such concession or institution was introduced for their grace, advantage, and favor, as was proven in the third consideration.

Therefore our kings are bound by natural and also divine law to avoid and guard against, both in the application and entry into those lands and in the progress, all disturbance, scandal, injustice, etc., and everything by which such end can be impeded or retarded or made difficult to obtain, in which things indeed a negative precept is included, no one ought to doubt, namely not to make disturbance, not to give cause for scandal, not to place an offense to the gospel, not to impede the progress of the faith and the conversion of souls, not, finally, to omit applying those things which can prohibit prohibiting things, and many things of this kind which are contained under negative precepts and are prohibited by their force.

¶ Second, the same second part is proven through the locus from contraries or opposites, because it belongs to the same to pursue one of contraries and to refute or exclude the other, as is clear. For medicine works health; consequently it strives to exclude illness with what force it can. It is of the same reason to be moved upward and downward. And therefore it is said that the matter, power, and discipline of contraries is the same,
2 De coelo et mundo 2 Rhetoricorum 1 and 6 Topicorum 4 and 8 Physicorum and 11 Metaphysicae, and by the legists l. et si contra in fine ff. de vulgari et pupillari and
institut: de his qui sunt sui vel alieni iuris, in principio.

Hence one tending toward any natural end is moved by two things, of which the first is the flight and removal of that which is an impediment to motion toward the end and makes one deviate from the end. But the other is adhesion and tension of that which is leading to the end, and this according to the two integral parts of justice by which virtues are acquired, namely by declining from evil and doing good. Thus says
Henry of Ghent in his Summa of Theology article 24 question 4 . And thus it is clear that avoiding the contrary of that which is intended as end in mortal matters falls under the precept of natural justice.

¶ Third, the same second part is proven because unless our kings guard against or avoid the aforesaid contrary, inconvenient, and prohibiting things in their advent and entry, or that of their own, and similarly in the progress, without doubt they would be the privative cause of any good. For anyone is said to be, and is, the privative cause of any good, to whom by special law, as for instance from office or stipend, it falls to obtain something, and yet he omits through negligence or carelessness to remove the impediments of the thing to be obtained. Just as a sailor is bound by his office not only to lead the ship to port, but truly also to guard against the ship perishing by shipwreck in the shallows while sailing. And soldiers who are hired are obligated not only to defend the city by fighting bravely in conflict, but also to keep watch and to be supremely careful lest it be captured by enemies through ambushes and secretly.

Thus also our princes of the Spains, who have been hired (so to speak) by the Apostolic See at great stipend, and by special law, that is, from the office incumbent on them, are bound to be supremely careful and to remove, not in any manner but efficaciously, whatever impediments by which the prementioned end can be removed or impeded or even retarded. Otherwise, if through negligence or carelessness they omit these things, they will without doubt be the privative cause of the aforesaid goods, and consequently guilty of all the evils which through such omission and carelessness
will follow to the detriment of the faith and Christian religion and divine honor, and to the perdition of souls.

¶ Fourth, both parts are proven at once: Each one is obligated by necessity of salvation to those things which are of his office, to the exercise of which he has obligated himself, and for whose exercise and expenditure he has received payment. But our kings have obligated themselves to exercising those things which pertain to the office of kings in general, and beyond this by a certain peculiar law, that is, the office of apostles, to having care how, namely, the gospel of Christ may be preached and divine worship amplified and the name of the redeemer made known to all those Indian peoples in that whole world of the Indies, of the peoples, and their salvation may be procured. And for the expenditure of this exercise they have received great, indeed maximum, payment, although without payment they could have been obligated by the Apostolic See through precept. Therefore they are bound by force of precept and necessity of salvation to the aforesaid two things contained in this fifth consideration, namely by reason to proportion, moderate, and order their advent and first entry, or that of their own, and also the progress, that is, the regime and all other things which would have to be done by them concerning those lands and nations inhabiting that world, so that they may conduce or be suitable to the preaching and expansion of the faith and the conversion of souls; and consequently to guard against all contrary things which can stand in the way of these things, or remove or impede them, or in any way will be able to retard them. For both pertain to the office of the king, as appears from what has been said.

The consequence is clear with the major through
Saint Thomas 3rd part question 67 article 8 in the body , where he says that
each one is obligated to execute the office which he receives . And on the epistle 1 to Timothy in the prologue, he says that
prelates and superiors are bound by precept to those things which are of their proper office . And this obligation can be seen more clearly through the example of one who assumes advocating, healing, protecting, and teaching, and thus concerning other ministry, and has received payment for its administration or exercise, as is proven through the law qui mercedem ff. locati, with those noted there, and what is read and noted in l. dominus in principio and
C. mandati l.
in re mandata.
But the minor, namely that our kings are also obligated by a certain peculiar law, etc., is clear.

First, from their promise which passed into a pact as soon as the pope accepted it through his letters,
l. pactum, ff. de pollicita.
Hence it is said in the aforesaid decree: and moreover we command you by virtue of holy obedience, as you also promise, etc.

Second, because by formal precept the Supreme Pontiff bound them that through suitable ministers they should wish to induce the inhabitants and dwellers of the aforesaid world to receive the faith and be imbued with good morals, etc. Hence he added thus:
as you also promise (and we do not doubt, for your very great devotion and royal magnanimity, that you are going to do it), you ought to send to the aforesaid mainlands and islands good men fearing God, learned, skilled, and experienced, to instruct the aforesaid inhabitants and dwellers in the Catholic faith and imbue them with good morals, applying all due diligence in the aforesaid , etc. These things there in form. Where it is clear that our kings are bound by an obligation peculiar beyond that which is common to all kings to the aforesaid things. And we have disputed more diffusely concerning this in
our treatise On the War of Xalisco in the proof of a certain corollary 3 near the beginning of the work .

¶ But that our kings are in a certain way hired at a price for the aforesaid care and labor is clear, because they have been stipended at great stipend, with great gifts and maximum honors and immense dignity by the supreme vicar of Christ from the treasury of the Church, that is, by ecclesiastical power, for the office, namely, of the apostles, that is, of expanding the faith and converting souls. For our king is a certain apostle of those. Moreover, by temporal principate and antonomastic height, namely a supreme king over many and great kings, and also by incomparable riches of gold, silver, other metals, gems, pearls, emeralds, and of other things of that kind and various species, and finally by innumerable treasures, such as have never been heard of anywhere on earth or among peoples, either in number or value— provided, however, that our Catholic kings fulfill those things which they have promised and pledged.
